technology_categories.description: Only 5.9% of E&S organizations report advanced use of technology, with the majority (62.7%) describing their technology use as slight or moderate
Significant variance in digital maturity across the value chain, with distribution and policy administration showing highest technology penetration
Larger carriers and MGAs demonstrate higher technology adoption rates, with 2-3x the penetration rates of smaller players
Top areas where insurers have used technology include digitizing submissions, data analytics, desktop underwriting applications, and claims analysis
Technology spending in E&S has increased by 35-45% over the past five years
AI and automation tools are seeing the fastest growth in investment, with 50-60% year-over-year increases
Technology implementation typically delivers 15-30% efficiency improvements across core processes
AI-powered underwriting tools show the strongest ROI, with 15-25% improvements in loss ratios
E&S carriers with advanced technology capabilities show 3-5 percentage point better combined ratios than industry averages
Customer-facing processes show highest automation levels (quote generation, submission intake)
Policy administration and underwriting show moderate automation levels (40-60%)
Claims and complex underwriting show lowest automation levels (15-40%)
Straight-through processing rates vary significantly by line of business (highest in standardized E&S lines, lowest in complex specialty risks)
Large carriers (AIG, Berkshire Hathaway, Fairfax) and digital-native MGAs (Coalition, Openly) demonstrate most advanced capabilities
Significant gaps exist between market leaders and followers, particularly in AI adoption and API connectivity
Key differentiating capabilities include AI-powered risk assessment, seamless broker experiences, and API-first architectures
Embedded insurance platforms and parametric solutions represent the next frontier in E&S technology
What Is The ROI Of Digital Transformation In Insurance?
